lines.text: Mount up, Red Dog, they need the pros again.
[Noticing that the aircraft is approaching the airport from behind them, and lining up on the runway they occup]
He's coming in behind us... he's coming right at us!
Where is he going? He can't make the turn to 31.
Hey! He's coming in on 22.
Uh, Sir? that, uh, runway is closed. That's 22, Sir. But if you have to, you can line up on it.
Well, we're pretty well lined up now. How long is that runway?
Uh, United 232 Heavy. Okay, Sir. T-t-that will work. It's 6,600 feet, and the equipment's coming off.
Rescue One, this is Comm Center. What have you got there, dear?
She's down and burning! It's a big jet fuel fire. Bob says we got plenty of foam but not water. We need every truck full!
What about survivors?
I don't think so, Marg.
We must have taken out all the hydraulics lines at once, is that possible?
Well, they all come together back there.

Get on the yoke with me, will you? I don't know if it's doing any good or not, but it's all we got. You need to handle the number three throttles too. I can't handle them both. Dudley, what does the manual say?
See page I-63.
232, systems maintenance. Understand you have normal power on number one and number three engine?
Maintenance, 232, affirmative. We need help on loss of all, repeat, all hydraulic systems. What have you got, Dudley?

[frantically]
Main bus, main backup, the hell! It doesn't say anything about all three out! It's not supposed to happen!
Minneapolis Center, United 232 Heavy.
232, go ahead.

Sir, we have a problem. We have no hydraulic fluid, which means we have no elevator control, almost none. We have a little aileron control. We're trying to steer with throttles only. I have serious doubts about reaching destination. Do you know someplace nearby where we might be able to land? If I don't take control of this airplane soon, I'll have to put her down wherever she happens to be.
232, Roger. Standby one.
[pause]
232, systems maintenance. You might try flight manual, page I-63.
I'm on I-63!
232 Heavy, Minneapolis Center. Do you wish to declare an emergency?
Yes, Sir! That is affirmative. We'd appreciate all the help we can get.
Tell you what. We'll all have a beer when we get this sucker down.
I don't drink, but I'll sure as hell have one on that!
[picking up the telephone]
Sioux City Tower? Say again? 232 Heavy? Confirm me heavy. Understand, a DC-10 squawking 7700. Roger, standing by.
[to Porter]
Minneapolis Center. Get set for an emergency hand-off.
A DC-10?
Yeah. Tail engine blown out, no hydraulics. Only control he's got is right and left throttle. Poor bastard's circling high and looking for a place to land.
You wanna take approach control?
No, you'll do fine. I'm right behind you.
[after checking the tail of the aircraft]
Hell Number 2 must've blown up there's a chunk this big torn out of the right side stabilizer.

United 232, the airport's currently at your one o'clock position, ten miles. Sir, if you can't make it to the airport, there's a Interstate that runs North to south, to the East side of the airport. That's a four-lane interstate.
Roger, Sioux, we're just passing it now. We're going to try for the airport.
United 232 Heavy, Roger, and advise when you do get runway 31 in sight.
Where's...
I got the runway!
I don't.
There! Back on number one, back on one.
Okay, I see it! Let's try to keep the descent at 500 feet per minute.
I see the tower! We have the airport in sight. We'll be with you very shortly, thanks a lot for your help.
United 232 Heavy, Roger, Sir. Wind 010 at 11. You are cleared to land on any runway.

[chuckles]
You want to be particular in making a runway?
[staff at the control tower laugh nervously]
He's gonna make it!
Do I understand, a DC-10?
Affirmative.
What is that, like 200 people?
Rescue One, capacity more like 300 and 80,000 pounds of jet fuel.

[to a colleague]
Okay, we're gonna need lots more foam. And vehicles.

[to Zubinski]
You tell 'em we'll be ready.
Okay, Sioux. We dumped fuel down to 37. And with four in the cockpit, that's 296 souls on board.
[pause]
Uh... 232 Heavy, copy, 292 souls on board plus four in the cockpit, and 37 thousands pounds of fuel. Roger sir, continue approach.
This is Sioux Tower, to all rescue units, we have an Alert Three. I say again, we are declaring an Alert Three. A DC-10 in emergency approach. 296 souls on board. 35 miles Northeast.
Sioux Tower, Rescue One, Roger your Alert Three. We're calling every unit in the tri-state area.
Rescue One, Roger. You've got about 15 minutes to get them here.
this is not a drill!

[over the P.A]
Okay, folks. Brace! Brace! Brace!
232, looking good, Sir! And be advised that there is nothing but open field at the end of the runway, so roll-out will *not* be a problem!
232, Roger. Ease the power back now. Left turns. Left turns. Easy... Too fast!
Whoop! Whoop! Pull up! Glideslope!
Left... left... left...
Your nose...
Whoop! Whoop! Pull up! Glideslope!
Left! Left! Left!
Too fast!
Whoop! Whoop! Pull up! Glideslope!
Left! Left!
God!
Whoop! Whoop! Pull up! Glideslope!
[impact]

we're currently cruising at 37,000 feet, just passing over the town of Alta, Iowa, estimating arrival in Chicago right on time. Weather along our flight route will be perfect. We hope you're enjoying your lunch.
[flight attendant knocks on the door]
Come in!
[flight attendant enters, brings the food trays]
We're still high on Aloha food. Who wants the Ahi tuna?
Mahalo!
[an explosion rocks the aircraft, and a deafening, high-pitched engine noise starts]
What the hell?
Low pressure going on two!
Two's gone. Shut it off.
Number two throttle's stuck there.
Okay, emergency shut down. Engine start lever and fire handle to cut-off.
[Records pulls down a red lever, and it visibly reduces noise and vibration]
Okay, that's good.
The elevator's sluggish.
We're losing hydraulic pressure.
We need back-up hydraulics!
Roger.
[flips a switch, all lights indicate "Pressure Low"]

[frantically]
Backup's two and three losing pressure too, Skipper!
[first lines, narration]

The approach to Sioux Gateway Airport, under normal circumstances, is a pilot's delight. You cross the Missouri River, pass the tip of South Dakota. Nebraska's on your right. On your left, the farmlands of Iowa. As you get closer to the airport, in the fields between the runways, they grow soybeans and corn. It's in one of these cornfields that our story begins...
How did it feel to save that boy?
God saved that boy, I just CARRIED him.
There he is.
Mmmm-hmmm.
Sioux City, United 2-3-2 Heavy.
United 232 Heavy Sioux City Approach.
Ah, Roger... we are in a bit of a rough patch here, you got us squawk.
Roger 232, radar contact five-niner miles. Your present track will put you about eight miles north of the airport, sir. Ah... can you make a slight left turn sir?
Ah... hope to make some slight left turns on final, but right now we gotta make right turns only, to whatever heading you want.
Roger 232 Heavy, ah... right turn heading two-five-five
All units this is Sioux City Tower, we have an alert two, I say again alert two, get two more guys up here now please.
Whatever you do, keep us away from the city.
I'm just beginning to feel it.
Feel what?

Stress. You know what it's called just as well as I do, post-traumatic stress. We're all going to go through it. When this is all over, we're all going to need a little therapy, and just plain talking to people we love.
What are you saying, I'm flipping out?
I don't want you taking anymore meetings, no more 5 AM thank-you letters. Go home and you sleep. I know you will. I just laced your coffee.
You did not.
No, but I'll belt you if I have to.
Alright, alright. Where did you get your bedside manner? College?
No, I was an English major. My medical degree is from Vietnam.
[ATC Chris Porter is visiting Capt. Haynes in the hospital]
Well sir, you look real good.
I tell you, it sure beats rigor mortis.
I read in the paper that United put your flight track up on their Denver simulator. A lot of senior pilots tried to land the planes. So far nobody has gotten within ten miles of the airport.
Well they didn't have you talking them down.
I had a lot of help.
But you have no idea what your calm voice meant to us up there.

[choking up]
Well Captain, I-I really think I might've done a better job.

Join the club! Listen, Chris, of all the places in America we could've landed, I thank God it was here. I intend to tell that to every man, woman, and child in this city, if I have to come back here a hundred times.
Denver Tower, this is United 232 heavy, ready for take-off, 35 Right.
232 heavy, cleared for take-off, 35 Right, and have a good day sir.
Denver Tower, roger that, cleared for take-off runway 35 Right... and you have a good one too.
Better pick up. It's Marg at the Comm Center!
Yeah, Marg?
I... I just got a call from Sioux Tower. Get on the loop.
I'm on.
Understand Sioux City is option one after Des Moines. Is pilot aware Sioux Gateway's longest runway is 9,000 feet?
Sioux City, at this time pilot is just, uh, looking for a home.
Roger, standing by.
[pause]
My God. Rich! Rich! Get the comm trailer out to Gateway, I think we got something going on. Heidi? This one's real!
[over P.A]
2403 Ogden Avenue, Sioux Gateway Airport, Alert Two.
